name: K2-203
scenarioDescription:
The K2-203 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-203 is a star with 0.79 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.76 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system.

K2-203 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-203 system


K2-203 b

K2-203 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is NaN astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-203 b is 2.4549600000000003 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-203 b is 1.371 that of Earth. At 2.4549600000000003 Earth masses, K2-203 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-203, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
